description:
## Overview
Update the Figma canvas changelog entries to match the new design from Figma mockup (node 8-577). This involves restructuring the layout, updating typography, and improving readability.

## Design Reference
Figma URL: https://www.figma.com/design/lo3m4RaUflEKapP7AftylE/ito---Design?node-id=8-577

## Key Changes

### 1. Header Section
- Gray background (#efefef light / dark equivalent)
- "Version X.X.X" with "Version" in muted color, number in primary
- Author + timestamp on separate line
- Title (bold, 16px) and description (regular, 13px) below

### 2. Comments Section
- Section header: "COMMENTS" uppercase with orange (#fa4f0b) pill badge showing count
- Each comment shows:
  - Author + timestamp (gray, 11px)
  - Comment body (medium, 12px, dark)
  - Reply context if threaded: "Reply to: ..." (truncated)
  - Node reference: "Node: X:XXX"

### 3. Annotations Section
- Section header: "ANNOTATIONS" uppercase with blue (#345ccc) pill badge showing count
- Each annotation shows:
  - Title (semibold, 16px)
  - Properties in columnar layout (label: value)
  - Only show properties that have values
  - Pin icon (ðŸ“Œ) for pinned items

### 4. General Styling
- White/dark card background
- 8px rounded corners
- Sections separated by border (#e0e0e0)
- 24px padding for content, 32px top padding for header
- Support both light and dark themes

### 5. Click-to-Navigate
- Add click interaction to navigate to referenced nodes
- Comments: click to navigate to comment's node
- Annotations: click to navigate to annotated layer

## Implementation Tasks
- [ ] Update header section layout and styling
- [ ] Implement comments section with count badge
- [ ] Implement annotations section with columnar properties

title: Fix histogram tooltip positioning to stay within plugin window
description:
## Problem
Tooltips on the Recent Activity histogram sometimes fall outside the plugin window, making them unreadable. This happens when:

1. Hovering over histogram bars on the left edge - tooltip's left side gets cut off
2. Hovering over histogram bars on the right edge - tooltip's right side gets cut off
3. For tall histograms, the tooltip may appear above the viewport

## Expected Behavior
Tooltips should always be fully visible within the plugin window, regardless of which bar is hovered.

## Requirements
- Detect when tooltip would render outside viewport bounds
- Dynamically adjust tooltip position (horizontal flip, vertical flip, or both) to stay within bounds
- Maintain tooltip's relationship to the hovered bar (still clear which bar it's associated with)
- Preserve current tooltip styling and content

## Technical Context
- Current implementation: `packages/figma-plugin/src/components/HistogramPanel.tsx`
- Tooltip is positioned using `fixed` positioning with `transform: translate(-50%, -100%)`
- X/Y position is calculated from `event.currentTarget.getBoundingClientRect()`
- Plugin window dimensions available via `window.innerWidth` / `window.innerHeight`
close_reason: Implemented tooltip positioning logic to keep tooltips within plugin window bounds

title: Improve comment thread rendering to show reply hierarchy
description:
Update changelog canvas rendering to differentiate initial comments from replies.

Current state: All comments in a thread are rendered the same way

Desired state: 
- Identify if a comment is a reply vs. initial comment
- Render replies with context: "Reply to: [original comment truncated to 1 line]"
- Maintain visual hierarchy to show thread structure

Investigation needed:
- Check Figma API response structure for comment threads/replies
- Determine if reply relationship data is available
- Design visual treatment for reply comments
notes:
IMPLEMENTATION COMPLETE:

Changes made:
1. Updated Comment type to include 'id' and 'parentId' fields
2. Updated fetchComments() to capture comment IDs and parent relationships from Figma API
3. Updated commentFingerprint() to use comment ID as primary key (more reliable)
4. Updated createCommentItem() to accept parent comment text and display reply context
5. Updated createCommentsSection() to organize comments into threads

How it works:
- Figma API provides parent_id field on comments (if present, comment is a reply)
- Figma supports one-level threading only (replies to root comments, not replies to replies)
- Root comments are rendered normally
- Reply comments are indented and show: 'Reply to: [parent comment truncated to 1 line]'
- Comments are organized into threads: root comment followed by all its replies

Threading structure:
- Comments with no parentId are root comments
- Comments with parentId are replies
- Replies are rendered indented with parent context
- Parent text is truncated to ~60 characters for display
close_reason: Implemented comment thread rendering with reply hierarchy. Replies now show 'Reply to: [parent comment]' context with indentation. Uses Figma API parent_id field to organize comments into threads.

Fix changelog diff inconsistencies - use timestamp-based filtering for comments
description:
Problem: Changelog entries show inconsistent diffs. If previous entry has 0 comments/annotations, next entry includes ALL elements from beginning of file.

Root Cause: filterNewComments and filterNewAnnotations use fingerprint matching against previous commit elements. When previous commit is empty, ALL elements match as new.

Solution: 
1. Comments: Use timestamp-based filtering (comment.created_at > previousCommit.timestamp) - REST API provides created_at but NOT modified_at
2. Annotations: Keep fingerprint-based filtering (no timestamps in Plugin API), add edge case handling for 0-entry commits
3. Allow empty commits with correct filtering

Technical Approach:
- Modify filterNewComments() to use timestamp comparison instead of fingerprints
- For annotations: Keep fingerprints, add special handling when previous commit has empty array to prevent reappearing all historical annotations
- May need to track global annotation fingerprints across all commits, or determine if 0-entry is first commit vs subsequent

Files to Modify:
- packages/figma-plugin/src/main.ts - filterNewComments(), filterNewAnnotations() functions

comments.author: Ryan Uesato
comments.text: Implemented timestamp-based filtering for comments and all-history filtering for annotations. Changes committed in 86d992b.

title: Comments not appearing in Figma canvas changelog
description:
New annotations are rendered in changelog entries on Figma canvas, but comments are not appearing. When inspecting the rendered changelog's layers, there is no Comments container nor any individual comment layers visible.

Comments are fetched from Figma API but are not being rendered in the createCommitEntryFrame function.
notes:
ROOT CAUSE IDENTIFIED AND FIXED:

The issue was caused by clock skew between client time (new Date()) and Figma server time (comment created_at). The code was using timestamp-based filtering which failed when:
- User creates Version A at client time 10:00:00
- User creates comment at client time 10:00:05
- Figma server saves comment with server timestamp 9:59:58 (2s behind)
- User creates Version B
- filterNewComments() filters out comment because 9:59:58 is NOT > 10:00:00

FIX IMPLEMENTED:
Restored fingerprint-based deduplication (matching author|text|nodeId) instead of timestamp comparison. This approach:
1. Avoids clock skew issues entirely
2. Matches the proven approach used for annotations
3. Was originally implemented in commit 5091517 but mistakenly reverted

The fix compares comment content (author|text|nodeId fingerprint) against ALL previous comments from ALL commits, ensuring duplicates are filtered out without timing issues.
close_reason: Fixed by restoring fingerprint-based comment deduplication. Clock skew between client and Figma server no longer affects comment filtering. Comments now use same proven approach as annotations (author|text|nodeId fingerprinting).

title: Plan: Dynamic changelog rebuild from commit history
description: Research and plan how to dynamically rebuild the changelog if entries on the Figma canvas are accidentally deleted. Determine what data sources are available, whether external storage is needed, and design the rebuild strategy.
notes:
## Analysis Complete

### Three Data Layers
1. **clientStorage** â€” Full Commit objects (comments, annotations, metrics, title, description, author, timestamp, changelogFrameId)
2. **Canvas frames** â€” Visual rendering on the Changelog page (read-only display)
3. **Figma version history** â€” Just a string: 'version - title'

### Rebuild Feasibility by Scenario
- **Canvas frames deleted, clientStorage intact** â†’ FULL rebuild possible
- **clientStorage cleared, canvas intact** â†’ PARTIAL (fragile text parsing)
- **Both deleted** â†’ MINIMAL (version history titles + re-fetched comments, but lose grouping)

### Recommendation
Phase 1: Rebuild from clientStorage (simple, covers primary use case)
Phase 2: Redundant storage via sharedPluginData (resilience)

4. **Styling**:
   - Background: #2c2c2c
   - Fields: #383838
   - Typography: Inter font family
   - Rounded corners throughout (8px, 16px, 32px)
   - Clean, modern dark theme

## Requirements

- MUST preserve all existing functionality
- Update UI to match Figma design exactly
- Maintain all current features and capabilities
- Ensure interactive elements (histogram bars) work as expected

- [ ] Update component structure to match new design

title: Fix changelog diff inconsistencies - use timestamps instead of fingerprint matching
description:
## Problem

Changelog entries show inconsistent diffs:

1. If a previous changelog entry has 0 comments/annotations (no elements changed, but entry created anyway), the next entry includes ALL elements from the beginning of the file
2. Current implementation uses fingerprint matching to filter elements, which doesn't handle this case correctly
3. This behavior is confusing - elements reappear even though they haven't changed

## Root Cause

- filterNewComments() and filterNewAnnotations() use fingerprint matching against previous commit's elements
- When previous commit has empty comments/annotations, ALL elements match as new
- Comments have timestamps but we're not using them for filtering
- Annotations don't have timestamps, so fingerprint is the only current option

## Solution

1. Comments: Use timestamp-based filtering
   - Only include comments created AFTER previous commit timestamp
   - Also handle edited comments (if Figma API provides modification time)
   
2. Annotations: Add timestamp to Annotation type
   - Check if Figma Plugin API provides annotation modification timestamps
   - If available, use timestamp-based filtering like comments
   - If not available, keep fingerprint-based filtering but handle 0-entry case

3. Empty commits: Allow but fix the diffing logic
   - Continue allowing commits with 0 comments/annotations
   - Fix filtering to handle case where previous commit had 0 elements

## Technical Approach

- Update filterNewComments() to use timestamp comparison instead of fingerprints
- Check Figma API for node.annotations timestamp availability
- If timestamps available for annotations, update Annotation type in packages/core/src/types.ts
- If not available, add special handling for empty previous commit case in filterNewAnnotations()

## Files to Modify

- packages/figma-plugin/src/main.ts - filterNewComments(), filterNewAnnotations() functions
- packages/core/src/types.ts - Annotation interface (if adding timestamp)
